claim: In the EU, most people are not Muslim in any country.

supporting.text: According to Eurostat data, the majority of the population in all EU member states identifies as Christian or non-religious.

attacks.text: According to Eurostat data, the majority of the population in all EU member states identifies as Christian or non-religious.
Eurostat data may not account for unregistered or undocumented Muslim populations in some EU countries.
Official census and survey methodologies used by Eurostat are designed to capture all residents, including undocumented populations, through sampling techniques.
Some EU countries, like France, have significant Muslim populations that may approach or exceed 10% of the total population, challenging the notion of 'most' being non-Muslim.
Even in countries with higher Muslim populations like France, the majority (over 50%) still identifies as Christian or non-religious, consistent with the original claim.

supporting.text: Pew Research Center reports that Muslims constitute less than 10% of the population in every EU country as of 2025.

attacks.text: Pew Research Center reports that Muslims constitute less than 10% of the population in every EU country as of 2025.
Pew Research Center's methodology may not account for undocumented immigrants, who may disproportionately include Muslims.
Undocumented immigrants are unlikely to significantly alter the overall demographic percentages due to their relatively small numbers.
Some EU countries have rapidly growing Muslim populations due to higher birth rates and immigration, potentially exceeding 10% soon after 2025.
Projections based on current trends still show Muslim populations remaining below 10% in most EU countries for the foreseeable future.

supporting.text: Official census data from EU countries consistently shows that Islam is not the majority religion in any member state.

attacks.text: Official census data from EU countries consistently shows that Islam is not the majority religion in any member state.
Census data may undercount Muslim populations due to undocumented migrants or reluctance to disclose religious affiliation in some countries.
Government census methodologies in EU countries are rigorously designed to minimize undercounting, including outreach to marginalized communities.
In certain cities like Marseille or Rotterdam, Muslims may constitute local majorities despite not being national majorities.
The claim specifically refers to country-level demographics, making city-level exceptions irrelevant to the original statement.
Some EU nations like Bulgaria have significant Muslim minorities (15%+) that challenge the notion of uniform religious distribution.
A 15% minority still confirms Islam isn't the majority religion, which aligns perfectly with the original claim's wording.

supporting.text: Demographic studies indicate that even in EU countries with significant Muslim populations, they remain a minority compared to other religious or non-religious groups.

attacks.text: Demographic studies indicate that even in EU countries with significant Muslim populations, they remain a minority compared to other religious or non-religious groups.
Some EU cities or regions, such as Marseille in France or parts of Brussels, have Muslim populations approaching or exceeding 50% of the local population.
Even in cities with high Muslim populations, they remain a minority at the national level in all EU countries.
Demographic projections suggest that Muslim populations in some EU countries may become the majority within a few decades due to higher birth rates.
Projections are uncertain and depend on variables like immigration policy and assimilation rates, making current minority status more reliable.

supporting.text: EU-wide surveys on religious affiliation demonstrate that no single country has a Muslim majority population.

attacks.text: EU-wide surveys on religious affiliation demonstrate that no single country has a Muslim majority population.
Some EU countries, such as Cyprus, have significant Muslim populations that may approach majority levels in certain regions.
Even in Cyprus, official statistics show that the Muslim population is below 50% nationally, maintaining the claim's validity.
The definition of 'Muslim majority' can vary depending on whether it includes nominal or practicing Muslims, potentially altering the interpretation.
Standard demographic surveys consistently define Muslim affiliation based on self-identification, not practice, ensuring reliable comparisons.
